title: fixing possible safety issue with altitude

conversation.author: catch-twenty-two
conversation.body: Ignoring requested altitude from target for now.

conversation.author: pickledgator
conversation.body: Descend was unimplemented in navigator, and thus had no effect when the navigation state was changed. Utilized same land helper. Downstream logic in pos_control and commander successfully ignore position data that is applied in the setpoint message. Tested in gazebo for multi-rotors.

issue_comments.author: julianoes
issue_comments.body: Nice catch. How did you find this, in which scenario did the bug show up?

issue_comments.author: pickledgator
issue_comments.body: To support development, I needed a way to trigger a failsafe landing without xy position control, even when position data is available in the filter (eg., bad VO). Descend nav state provides the control mechanism that I desired, and I piped an RC channel to a new failsafe main state to trigger the Descend.

title: VTOL_TAKEOFF, VTOL_LAND commands and VT_FORCE_VTOL param

conversation.author: sanderux
conversation.body:
support for MAV_CMD_NAV_VTOL_TAKEOFF and MAV_CMD_NAV_VTOL_LAND 
Also implement VT_FORCE_VTOL to force land as VTOL
replaces https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/3720

Fixes #3492
Fixes #3712

issue_comments.author: sanderux
issue_comments.body:
@AndreasAntener I cleaned up the mission code, sanitized the functionality, improved back transition behavior, fixed alignment and implemented force_vtol procedure.
SITL tested all reasonable scenarios and regression tested on the old procedure (takeoff -> trans -> wp -> trans -> land).

I'm especially happy with the back transition improvement, we could see if the basis could change from time to velocity but for now this seems to be a big improvement.

I will test fly this tree soon but i think it is ready to rebase and merge as i see no possible regression and it only implements previously unsupported functionality.

Somehow this tagged along through a submodule init and causes travis to fail: https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/4055/files#diff-d62dbab64e619e0e5926b64585204efdR1
I think that should be resolved by rebasing but i'm not sure.

/cc @LorenzMeier @tumbili

issue_comments.author: LorenzMeier

issue_comments.author: sanderux
issue_comments.body: This should fix the yaw issue during transition

issue_comments.author: AndreasAntener
issue_comments.body: @sanderux before I forget, mission item reached: one reason to not wait on the transition to be finished is that the position controller won't know the next waypoint and therefore cannot control the position during the transition in case we later implement this. haven't thought about it in detail though.

issue_comments.author: sanderux
issue_comments.body:
the advantage of this command is that the user can point the vehicle into the wind. It is basically the autonomous equivlant of flicking the aux1 switch.

For position control it should hold altitude and heading until ttansition has completed or timeout occurs.

issue_comments.author: AndreasAntener
issue_comments.body:
Sure but it's changing the behaviour in general, also for the separate transitions (not part of VTOL tko/lnd). What we talked about yesterday, if we want the FW position controller to guide it through blending, it needs to know the next waypoint. If it doesn't get the actual next mission waypoint, we need to generate a temporary waypoint that lies in the direction of the target transition heading. Another option would be to look at the "next" waypoint in the triplet, which contains the next position during the transition. Ok, I think we have 2 good options here so it's fine.

Note: simply holding heading and attitude is not going to work, it will drift off path.

issue_comments.author: sanderux
issue_comments.body: Yes your right, i think a temp waypoint would be a good idea.

title: FW navigator accept TAKEOFF waypoint like MC (alt only)

conversation.author: dagar
conversation.body: I think this makes the most sense for fixed wing behaviour. You're still flying towards the takeoff waypoint, but once you actually hit the altitude (within NAV_ACC_RAD) you're ready to proceed with the mission.

issue_comments.author: dagar
issue_comments.body:
I was also thinking about updating MissionFeasibilityChecker. What would be appropriate?

-require altitude greater than: At least home + climbout_diff + nav_acc_rad or MIS_TAKEOFF_ALT?
-minimum distance >= FW_AIRSPEED_TRIM \* FW_T_CLMB_MAX meters from home.

issue_comments.author: AndreasAntener
issue_comments.body: Both options are not ideal. Caring for horizontal position might make it turn too soon, caring for altitude might make it spiral where you don't want it. At least with the way it is now you know what it will do (because you have the next waypoint in mind). The spiral might be completely unexpected. But other than that I can't really argue for one or the other.

issue_comments.author: dagar
issue_comments.body:
I'm more concerned with the current situation making it accept too soon when you should still be climbing with roll constrained and TECS in climbout mode. With the roll limited to [-15, 15] during altitude_error > _parameters.climbout_diff the potential spiral is pretty limited depending on your FW_CLMBOUT_DIFF and NAV_ACC_RAD.

A fairly common situation is hand launching into wind where the plane climbs quickly and easily hits the takeoff altitude early. Why fly to a fairly low waypoint instead of continuing the mission?

Think of the takeoff waypoint as more of a cmd to launch + climb with its location not necessarily important.

issue_comments.author: AndreasAntener
issue_comments.body: You can't just assume that the takeoff position is not important to the user.

issue_comments.author: AndreasAntener
issue_comments.body: What your thinking off is not flying a mission but just flying manually where only the climbout diff is relevant.

issue_comments.author: dagar
issue_comments.body:
It's not necessarily assuming the takeoff position isn't important to the user (it would still be mostly respected if climbout diff > accept radius), but rather I'm trying to tweak what we already have to get the behaviour I want. Maybe that's the wrong approach.

So let's take a step back and have the proper discussion. I want to hand launch in AUTO, sometimes with launch detect, sometimes without and have that launch do nothing but safely climb in the direction I throw until a certain altitude, and then continue/start the mission. How could we accomplish this while still having the option of respecting a takeoff waypoint position?

issue_comments.author: AndreasAntener
issue_comments.body: Ok. Wasn't it your plan to reuse the runway takeoff code for hand launch too? I believe it would give you exactly what you want. In "heading mode" it will takeoff to climbout alt in the direction you threw it, and then navigate towards takeoff wp. In "wp mode" will directly try to navigate towards the takeoff waypoint (which is the default behaviour at the moment I guess?).

issue_comments.author: dagar
issue_comments.body:
You're right that will probably be exactly what I want in most cases if I just treat the takeoff waypoint like my first regular waypoint. My only concern then is the possibility that the waypoint could be accepted before RunwayTakeoffState::FLY. What would be the best way to prevent that?

Additionally check climbout diff to accept NAV_CMD_TAKEOFF or actually publish takeoff state?

conversation.author: dagar
conversation.body:
This also includes a minor fw_pos_control_l1 cleanup where the const arg pos_sp_triplet and _pos_sp_triplet were being used interchangeably.

Possible fix for #3902

issue_comments.author: LorenzMeier
issue_comments.body: Looking good to me. It still will require putting takeoff waypoints at a suitable minimum distance - which probably needs to be fixed in the GCS.

issue_comments.author: LorenzMeier
issue_comments.body: The change looked anyway good, so I cherry-picked it it onto master. Closing.

conversation.author: dagar
conversation.body:
This pull request introduces fixed wing airspeed mode. Airspeed mode is the minimum manual mode that's appropriate (safe) for an operator without RC experience.
It's a stabilized mode with manual throttle and airspeed controlled with the pitchstick. It feels similar to STAB, but you can't stall the plane.

**Questions**
- ~~where should this fit in with the existing modes and switches?~~
- ~~this mode is much better with the TECS time constant significantly reduced, could it scale automatically?~~ You just need to properly tune TECS
- ~~this doesn't currently work with mTecs, does anyone use it?~~
- ~~should this mode respect FW_THR_MIN/FW_THR_MAX?~~

issue_comments.author: dagar
issue_comments.body:
I tested most combinations of mode transitions to and from airspeed mode HIL today and didn't see any obvious problems.
Log muncher might be broken: http://logs.uaventure.com/view/GcnQdeGGB4qgMJDwX8HQng

Reinitializing TECS between airspeed mode and any other TECS mode is a bit abrupt, I'm going to try just resetting speed weight and the underspeed check instead.

I'll try an actual flight next week.

issue_comments.author: dagar
dagar
issue_comments.body: I've cherry-picked to stable for flight testing. https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/compare/stable...dagar:fw_airspeed_mode-stable?expand=1

issue_comments.author: dagar
issue_comments.body: @SimonWilks is this new mode killing logmuncher? http://logs.uaventure.com/view/tNysut35PRAqfF8qe2xhr7

issue_comments.author: dagar
AndreasAntener
issue_comments.body:
This confused me a bit so I hope you don't mind my questions. I had to look in the code to understand how this is supposed to work ;).

How is this different from altitude control from the users perspective? Maybe you could explain a bit where the need for this mode is coming from?

Don't you have 2 inputs that have an effect on altitude now? So I'm assuming thrust is your main altitude control now (with speed-weight 2). But also if you change the airspeed setpoint TECS will have to dive/climb (because it has no other means anymore of matching the speed)?

issue_comments.author: dagar
issue_comments.body:
Think of it as a safe manual mode. Similar to stabilized mode, but the autopilot maintains a safe airspeed [FW_AIRSPEED_MIN, FW_AIRSPEED_MAX] at all times to prevent the vehicle from stalling. It's very useful for manually landing a UAV. In a locked down configuration for a user this would be their manual mode (which they wouldn't expect to hold altitude).

This airspeed mode is actually what several commercial UAVs and autopilots refer to as manual mode.

You should try it in a simulator with appropriate min, trim, and max airspeeds and possibly reducing the TECS time constant. It feels like flying in stabilize mode, but the pitch responds a bit slower.

issue_comments.author: AndreasAntener
issue_comments.body:
Landing, that's interesting. I mean, you have the same problem here as in alt/posctl: you cannot flare. How does the stick movement look for a landing? Wouldn't you want to reduce airspeed AND throttle for a landing?

Naive question: have you tried plain altitude control with a reduced TECS time constant? I know you don't have manual throttle there, just wondering if the control feeling would already be better then.

> This airspeed mode is actually what several commercial UAVs and autopilots refer to as manual mode.

Could you give me an example? (because I'm curious, not because I don't believe you :))

issue_comments.author: dagar
issue_comments.body:
Actually you can flare by pulling the pitch stick completely back, assuming you approach above min airspeed. Having direct control over throttle makes this mode much safer than ALTCTL for handling on the ground at launch or landing.

I haven't tried ALTCTL with a reduced TECS time constant, but I generally use it when I want to just stay at the same altitude and not think about it.

The Procerus Kestrel autopilot (acquired by Lockheed) and fixed wing UAVs from AeroVironment refer to this as manual mode.

issue_comments.author: dagar
issue_comments.body: I've flown this a couple times and it works as intended with no problems, but the airspeed response isn't great. I've been having a hard time tuning TECS to respond nicely for this mode, but still work well normally.

issue_comments.author: AndreasAntener
issue_comments.body: @dagar What about leaving airspeed control away if within min/max? There is a lot of talk about stall prevention ATM. I believe your reasoning behind this "airspeed" mode is not different from people simply requesting stall prevention methods. Maybe it could be more of a mix, having manual throttle/pitch/roll control, but start limiting pitch/roll when airspeed gets borderline, and use TECS to pitch down if airspeed falls below min.

issue_comments.author: tubeme
issue_comments.body:
@dagar Sounds very promising.

@AndersonRayner Here is what the APM is doing about stall:

> when in roll controlled modes the autopilot will monitor your demanded bank angle and airspeed and work out if you have sufficient margin above the stall speed to turn at the demanded bank angle. If you don’t then the turn will be limited to the safe limit, but it will always allow a bank of at least 25 degrees (to ensure you can still maneuver if your airspeed estimate is badly off).

We've seen this technique in other two more simpler controllers and it works.

> when in auto-throttle modes the autopilot will also raise the minimum airspeed in the TECS system to the level at which the current demanded bank angle can be safely achieved. So it will add more engine power or lower the nose to raise the airspeed so that the bank angle that the navigation controller is demanding can be achieved without a stall

They use these two parameters:

> The **STALL_PREVENTION** parameter. If this is set to zero then no stall prevention is done. This may be useful if you have no airspeed sensor and the synthetic airspeed estimate is not good 
> enough
> 
> The **ARSPD_FBW_MIN** parameter, which is the configured minimum airspeed for level flight. It is this value that is scaled with the bank angle to calculate the safe airspeed for any demanded bank angle

I'm not saying we have to copy, but there is not a big choice of approaches toward stall. It is classical physics.

issue_comments.author: dagar
issue_comments.body:
@AndreasAntener how would we keep TECS happy/initialized in between?

Hopefully I'll have some time to play around again later this week. I'll provide some plots of pitch input and response. It should be possible to get it to respond nicely when you're within the airspeed limits. Worst case I'll try doing airspeed control with only pitch outside of TECS.

conversation.author: julianoes

Do not merge yet, untested, just for review.

This is work in progress trying to clean up the vehicle_status message.
Current changes include:
- Remove circuit breakers from vehicle_status
- Delete mavlink compatible fields which were not in sync anymore.
- Move vtol_vehicle_status enum to vtol_status topic.
- Move battery calculations to the respective drivers (sensors.cpp and px4io.cpp).
- Move battery data to battery_status topic.
- Internalize condition bools into commander and out of vehicle_status.
- Use land_detected message everywhere instead of the landed bool in vehicle_status.

For more detailed explanations, please read through the commit messages.

This PR is now on top of #3857.

title: Px4.enhancement.3760.implement auto follow me.wip [WIP do not merge]

conversation.author: catch-twenty-two
conversation.body:
adds ability for px4 firmware to track a target.  Implements rudimentary following of target position in navigator.

Note: this uses a new version of the mavlink library with the proposed follow target method, will not work with current mavlink library version.

https://github.com/catch-twenty-two/mavlink

Also uses new version of qground control with follow me option implemented:

https://github.com/mavlink/qgroundcontrol/pull/2817

Some concerns:

Please comment on ideas for error checking on bad position sent from tracker.  (e.g. ignore tracker if new pos vector is x meters away and instead just loiter)

Does it make sense for the "follow previous - current line" following be activated for this?  (currently I have it activated) I guess this might come in handy for intermittent GPS being sent...

In both instances ( "follow previous - current line" on and off) the result is "jumpy" if the new sp is to close to the current set point. 

Maybe this entire follow feature needs to be treated more like an instance using the position control code, except instead of manual input it gets tracker input. Or maybe it needs to be some type of hybrid of both pos control and auto line/position following code.

Anyways, just some ideas, I'd like to get other's suggestions. 

@LorenzMeier had suggested using a predictive model if we have the target velocity. (this doesn't seem to be an option on my nexus 7 as it doesn't seem to output gps velocity)

Here is a video of the current implementation, Qground control has been coded to send out sinusoidal gps coors, you can see the jumpiness I am referring to:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qGC464eVI5E&feature=youtu.be

issue_comments.author: devbharat
issue_comments.body:
This reminded me of the target following I had implemented in APM a few years ago (used the same fixed wing libraries (l1 with TECS) as we do now) and the issues I faced. I did it by setting the target's position as the waypoints for the 'follower' (also I think I overwrote the current target waypoint with the latest waypoint I received from the target. Otherwise, the follower's position oscillated heavily). 
This strategy 'works' but you end up with steady state error between the target(say, moving in a straight line) and the follower (who never got directly in line behind the target, was always a bit to the left or the right). This can be seen in the following pic:

![dsc_0615](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3105122/13201714/9179428e-d87d-11e5-9f86-2a6d8ccab171.JPG)

You can see the green plane (fixed wing UAV) is following not directly behind the leader, but to the side. This was because unlike a single static waypoint, the waypoints in this case were constantly overwritten to the new target position values, with the controller never getting the time to correct the steady state error. This made me feel that, atleast for fixedwings, tracking moving targets required something more than just setting moving waypoints from the controls point of view.

You can see a mission with 3 aircrafts daisy-chained here:
![3-ac-lf-2013-09-28 13_41_29](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3105122/13201743/7d2f5934-d87e-11e5-85f1-1635b420890e.png)

issue_comments.author: LorenzMeier
issue_comments.body:
Awesome! I'm not so worried about the back and forth as my intention was not to keep sending a specific setpoint all the time, but to implement a "rubber-band" controller in that navigator class which trades smoothness for accuracy and only updates the next position gradually.

What I however indeed forgot is that we need to feed a desired velocity. That should be supported by the triplet as well. Or we can go straight to the position setpoint instead. I need to think about that and maybe we can discuss this on the dev call?

issue_comments.author: catch-twenty-two
issue_comments.body:
> What I however indeed forgot is that we need to feed a desired velocity. That should be supported by the triplet as well. Or we can go straight to the position setpoint instead. I need to think about that and maybe we can discuss this on the dev call?

Okay sounds good. Ill be on the call this morning, interested in hearing more about the controller you have in mind.

issue_comments.author: catch-twenty-two

I have to hold it very far away from the phone to get it to work correctly...Once it works though it works well...I'm going to play around with it some more to find the optimal placement for the radio. issue_comments.author: LorenzMeier
issue_comments.body: Replaced by https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/4065/files

review_comments.author: LorenzMeier
review_comments.body: In the section below are changes which exceed the changes needed for follow-me. Either this is a bad merge or the conditioning is incorrect (they should be guarded by if == FOLLOW_TARGET).

review_comments.author: catch-twenty-two
review_comments.body:
The above code uses a combination of overriding the velocity set point when it is appropriate while still using the position set point when it's not so I can take advantage of the velocity braking code as the position set point error delta gets smaller.  The code below overrides the velocity set point at all times and ignores the position set point for when the follow target module is in velocity tracking mode.  I was going to make a new set point type for the code below but saw that the position set point type already defined a set point type for velocity only, it just wasn't being used in the code anywhere. I used both of these set point types for a smooth transition between following using position and the velocity only tracking mode. Let me know if you still think I need to fix something or possibly have a better idea for what I am trying to accomplish.

Here is where I switch between the 2 tracking methods:

https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/3814/files?diff=unified#diff-35e82494becdfdcc5afaafb5b3f4e361R278

title: Yaw timeout for VTOL forwards transition

conversation.author: AndreasAntener
conversation.body:
This adds a yaw timeout on accepting the waypoint for the VTOL forwards transition because a VTOL might not reach yaw in wind. Fixes #3728

MIS_YAW_TMT
- default: -1
- > 0: timeout active on waypoints which force heading, ignore heading for acceptance on normal waypoints

MIS_YAW_TMT set to 10 seconds for default VTOL configurations

issue_comments.author: AndreasAntener
issue_comments.body:
@LorenzMeier @sanderux timeout and forcing the heading for a transition added. How does this look?

Already flew the timeout in real, new is the mission failsafe. If this is how we want it for the moment we can merge I think.
